            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Bengkulu Regional
            Development Project were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: When supported by adequate
            training and supervision village revolving grant program can
            be one of the surest ways of fighting poverty directly.
            Establishment of successful community-managed revolving
            funds has other important and valuable benefits in terms of
            capacity building, group empowerment and increased cohesion
            of the community. Taking the village as the entry point for
            project activities improves participation, ownership,
            capacity to absorb project supported changes, capture
            benefits and the sustainability of project interventions.
            Inclusion of adequate provision for M&E, preferably by a
            third party, should be essential for any project design, but
            it is crucially important for innovative projects. Where
            inclusion of areas, villages, groups or individuals are
            phased into the project over the implementation period, the
            arrangements for those taken in at the end of the project
            and their further support after credit/loan closure (exit
            strategy) needs to be already agreed at project mid-term review.
